content.description: An easy start leads into shallow crimps and a brief balancy crux to some victory jugs. Thin holds right where you need them makes this an awesome and fun TR.
content.protection: Sling a boulder or build a gear anchor for TR.
content.location:
Hike underneath and past the slabs leading to the cave/crack on

Short Barrel

up to a flat, grassy area below the short, clean wall. Choose whether to use the right-facing flake on

Unknown 5.6

to gain the clean headwall. See the topo.

content.description: Start by climbing through a reachy overhang to decent holds above. Once at the small ledge, pull onto the slab, and head for the seemingly suspect yet bomber jugs at the roof. Pull a final balancy crux, and finish up another short slab.
content.protection: Sling a boulder on top for a TR anchor. Using gear in cracks for directional support is recommended.
content.location:
Start at the broken block on the left (west) end of the large belay ledge above the lower slabs. It is about 20' left of

Small Game

.

climbs.name: There's A Snake In My Boot

content.description: A tricky sequence off the ground gets you to holds on the right arete. Use faint cracks and the arete until you can veer slight left through the upper headwall.
content.protection: Sling a boulder or build a gear anchor for TR. Watch for pendulum potential, and choose wisely when to veer left into the slab headwall.
content.location:
Hike underneath and past the slabs leading to the cave/crack on

Short Barrel

up to a flat, grassy area below the short, clean wall. Climb the right side of the wall, starting just left of a broken arete/right-facing corner. See the topo.

content.description: Start matched at the nice edge about head level. Climb tricky footwork off the ground into an easy cruise up to the top.
content.protection: There is a perfect, large boulder to sling for a TR anchor.
content.location:
Locate the wall with the route

Woody

and others. Continue from there heading east scrambling over a block past a bush to the short wall. This route is on the left end of the wall and starts at the obvious edge about head height.

content.description:
Start heading up large and dirty edges toward a hanging boulder on the slab above, trending right. It's easy (about 5.4 for the most part), but there is not much gear to be had if any on the slab. Continue through some hollow sounding rock until passing the hanging block and disappearing from your belayer into the wide chimney around to the right. Place some good gear high in the cracks within the chimney with a long runner. Finish climbing the short and fun chimney, and build an anchor or sling a large chockstone boulder with webbing or a cordalette.

Descend with easy scrambling/walk off to the right at the top of the chimney.
content.protection: A few pieces from 0.5 to 3 would be plenty. Bring webbing or a cordalette for building an anchor or slinging a chockstone boulder.
content.location:
Start just right of the belay for

Short Barrel

. Climb the slab into the recessed, wide corner that is hidden out of sight above on the headwall around the right side.

climbs.name: Super Soaker Slab
climbs.fa: Alex Hesler, TJ Aukamp, and Chris Obert

content.description:
Follow tier after tier of shallow bucket jug ledges up the water polished low angle slab staying just left of the corner. There is an easy Â walkoff after about 40', but keep going. This is very easy but a great climb on beautiful and clean rock. It is a nice pitch length to introduce someone new to climbing. Finish by stepping up and left on a huge detached flake, ending at a large, flat area directly below

Woody

and the other TRs.

This is a watercourse for the rock, so expect it to be wet with any recent precipitation.
content.protection:
Sling a boulder above or build a gear anchor to TR. It makes a pretty easy scramble to get from

Trigger

and

Small Game

to

Woody

and the other TRs above to the west.
content.location:
Head to the very lowest point of the formation, and look for a large, easy looking, low angle, left-facing corner. It climbs the clean slab face up the many obvious, large edges left of the corner. There are several easy ways to scramble to the flat area below

Woody

west and uphill from the start of the climb to build a TR anchor.

content.description: Start by pulling a fun mantel through a short roof at the first bolt to a ledge. Pull onto the slab, and work up into the obvious corner/crack above.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. The last 10' or so could be protected by cams if you wanted.
content.location: On the east end of the formation, start above slabs on a large flat ledge. The slabs below could serve as a nice first friction pitch. A large square block at the lip of the first roof at about 15' marks the start.

content.description: Start by following thin finger cracks up the easy slab toward the small alcove below the crack. Place a couple good pieces at the lip, and climb out on hand and fist jams and a couple useful hidden holds within the crack.
content.protection: A single rack up to #4 should be fine. Use long cordalette or rope to sling a large boulder/chockstone in a constriction behind the rock on your climber's right side when you reach the top. Carefully climb the easy notch with your back to the right side to exit the top out area, and walk off/scramble to the right (east).
content.location: This is the obvious crack that splits the first tall part of the crag when approaching down the drainage. It's on the furthest left (west) end of the crag. See the photo.

content.description: Start up the corner/slab, and head straight up to the tree at the top.
content.protection: Sling the tree on top to set up a TR.
content.location:
Hike underneath and past the slabs leading to the cave/crack on

Short Barrel

up to a flat, grassy area below the short, clean wall. Start in the right-facing corner/slab at the furthest right end of the wall.

content.description:
This is a short, easy, and unintimidating slab that would be a good "adventure" sport lead for a first-timer with good protection. This is a trivial climb for anyone with experience and was primarily installed as practice for bolting on lead. Start up easy, blocky terrain clipping 2 bolts until moving left up the slabs past 2 more bolts, and scramble up to the belay ledge above. This can be combined with

Small Game

for a fun long pitch, or you can sling a large boulder near the base of

Small Game

for an anchor and walk off.
content.protection:
4 bolts and webbing to sling a large boulder for an anchor. It is possible to link to

Small Game

continuing through 4 more bolts to the anchor; however, this hasn't been done yet, so appropriate rope length for the link-up is TBD.
content.location:
This is kind of a pain to get to and requires a short bushwhack through the dense aspen grove along the base, while weaving over and under deadfall and boulders (adding some adventure to the climb so be sure to have your new leaders route finding this as well). Start at the base of the slab about 65' below

Small Game

. Look for a bolt above a blocky, right-facing corner in a small belay clearing near the base.

content.description: Start up the flake/corner to easy cracks on the slab up and to the left.
content.protection: Sling a big boulder with cordalette or build a gear anchor to TR. It could go clean on gear.
content.location:
Hike underneath and past the slabs leading to the cave/crack on

Short Barrel

up to a flat, grassy area below the short, clean wall. Climb the large, right-facing flake/corner on the left (west) side of the wall. See the topo.

content.description: Climb the wide crack with some hollow sounding rock near the start.
content.protection: A pad? This is too short and easy for anything but a solo/boulder attempt.
content.location:
It ascends the obvious crack to the right of

T.R. Burner

.
